unnormalised: ## Beyond Bollywood: Why You Should Experience a Film Festival
normalised: ## Beyond Bollywood: Why You Should Experience a Film Festival

unnormalised: Hey there, movie buffs! Ever feel like you’re stuck in a constant loop of the same old blockbusters and streaming recommendations? Craving something… different? Then let me tell you about film festivals. They're not just for serious film critics in berets; they're a fantastic way to discover hidden gems, support independent filmmakers, and soak up some serious cinematic culture.
normalised: Hey there, movie buffs! Ever feel like you’re stuck in a constant loop of the same old blockbusters and streaming recommendations? Craving something… different? Then let me tell you about film festivals. They're not just for serious film critics in berets; they're a fantastic way to discover hidden gems, support independent filmmakers, and soak up some serious cinematic culture.

unnormalised: Think of it as a mela, but instead of chaat and colourful bangles, you get screenings and Q&As with directors. From the Jio MAMI Mumbai Film Festival, a real highlight for any Bollywood fan looking beyond the mainstream, to smaller regional festivals, there's something for everyone. I still remember stumbling upon a short film at the International Film Festival of Kerala (IFFK) back in 2015 – completely changed my perspective on storytelling.

unnormalised: So why should you ditch Netflix for a film festival? Firstly, exposure. You'll see films you'd never find otherwise – documentaries that challenge your thinking, experimental shorts that push boundaries, and international features that offer a window into different cultures. Imagine finding the next 'Gully Boy' before everyone else!

unnormalised: Secondly, it’s about community. You’ll be surrounded by people who are genuinely passionate about cinema, sparking conversations and debates that you won’t find anywhere else. Plus, you might even get to rub shoulders with some rising stars or seasoned pros from the Indian film industry!

unnormalised: Thirdly, it’s accessible. Many festivals offer student discounts and package deals, making it a relatively affordable way to experience a diverse range of films. Some even have free outdoor screenings in places like Delhi’s India Habitat Centre! Just check their websites – you'll find all the deets on ticket prices (usually around Rs. 200-500 per film) and schedule details.

unnormalised: Finally, don't be intimidated! Film festivals aren’t just for cinephiles with PhDs. Come with an open mind, a willingness to explore, and maybe a comfy cushion for those marathon screenings. You might just discover your new favorite filmmaker or a film that stays with you long after you leave the cinema hall. So, ditch the popcorn and head to the nearest film festival! It could be just 5 km away from your home!
